name: Plain Dosa
history: Plain Dosa is a staple in South Indian cuisine. It's a type of thin pancake made from a fermented batter of rice and lentils, known for its crisp texture and unique taste.
description: Plain Dosa is a versatile and popular South Indian dish. It's a thin, crisp pancake made from a fermented rice and lentil batter and is typically served with chutney and sambar.

equipment.name: spatula
equipment.description: For spreading and flipping the dosas.

ingredients.quantity: for grinding and adjusting batter consistency

instructions.title: Prepare Dosa Batter
instructions.description: Soak the parboiled rice, urad dal, and fenugreek seeds in enough water to cover them for at least 6 hours or overnight. Drain the water and grind the mixture in a blender or grinder to make a smooth batter. Add water gradually to achieve a pourable consistency. The batter should be slightly thick and not runny.

instructions.title: Ferment the Batter
instructions.description: Transfer the batter to a large mixing bowl. Add salt and mix well. Cover the bowl and set it aside in a warm place to ferment for 8-10 hours or until the batter doubles in volume and shows bubbles on the surface.

instructions.title: Cook the Dosa
instructions.description: Heat a griddle or tawa over medium heat. Once hot, lightly grease it with oil. Pour a ladleful of the fermented batter onto the center of the griddle. Quickly spread the batter in a circular motion using the back of the ladle to form a thin pancake.

instructions.title: Crisp the Dosa
instructions.description: Drizzle a few drops of oil around the edges of the dosa. Cook until the underside turns golden brown and the edges start to lift. The dosa should be crisp and lightly browned.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Fold the dosa and remove it from the griddle. Serve immediately with chutney and sambar. Repeat with the remaining batter to make more dosas.

tips: The consistency of the batter is crucial for the perfect dosa. It should be neither too thick nor too runny.
Maintain a medium heat throughout cooking to avoid burning the dosa.
variations: For a healthier version, use brown rice in place of white rice.
Experiment with different types of chutneys like mint or peanut for a variety of flavors.

storage.shelfLife: The batter can be refrigerated for up to 2 days.
storage.instructions: Store the batter in an airtight container and stir well before using.

reheatingInstructions.instruction: Reheat the dosa on a hot griddle for a few minutes until warm and crispy.

presentationTips: Serve on a traditional banana leaf for an authentic experience.
Garnish with a slice of lemon and a sprig of coriander.
